Look at my second code example. That’d be how you load the classes.

This stuff is really new to me, cus I mainly work with basic private server crap, and basic GUIs. I have no understandings of abstract classes, interfaces, array lists, hash tables, and a whole lot of other things.

I read threw your class Pwnd and I semi understand the concepts of it.

I’ve looked threw RS2D because I know it uses interfaces for packet handling and I just might use some snippets of it.

Off to trial by error.

edit:
got this far and now im alittle stumped
am i going the right way?
I was reading alil bit from the javadocs

I belive add finds the class that is implementing the method in PacketHandler

item.title: Little question with interfaces
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

Only reason why Java has interfaces is because the developers decided not to use the concept of multiple inheritance. So whenever you run into the need to extend multiple classes, you should probably start thinking of a solution that involves interface(s).

Actually, that may not be the only reason why, but it’s a major reason.

Read full topic

item.title: Little question with interfaces
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:11, topic:235197”] Script o = (Script) c.newInstance();
OK Pwnd, but you are assuming that every class in the Scripts directory implements/extends Script. This may well be true for you, but if this guy doesn’t have something like that, whatever the reason, then reflection would be useful for determining if the class implements a certain interface.[/quote]if (o instanceof Script) {[br][br][size=1]Posted on: October 06, 2008, 06:02:03 am[/size][hr][quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:13, topic:235197”]Short said, an interface is where you define methods without ‘saying’ what they do. You then implement them in other classes where you specify what they do according to what you want them to do. Right?[/quote]Kinda/Sorta. They have more uses.

Read full topic

item.title: Little question with interfaces
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“ephemeral, post:10, topic:235197”]An interface can be seen as a specification fow a minimum requirement of methods in a certain class. When you implement an interface in a class, that class must contain all the methods that is contained in the implemented interface. You can of course still add new methods to this class aswell, as a normal class, but to add all methods contained in the interface is a minimum requirement.

Using interfaces would be a good idea when you know what methods you will be using in your project/package, but not the exact implementation. This means, people that uses your interface in a class, can implement these methods anyhow they like, but they need to be there.

Another good thing with interfaces is that you can have them as a container for constants, that is “public static final”. So, instead of importing a constant by class or static import, or extending a class that have constants, you now can implement (using “implements”) it instead.

The last but not least thing about interfaces I will mention, is that you can change the implementing classes without compiling the classes that uses these interface. That is, you only have to compile the implementing classes, unless you change more.

openice123: I noticed in your second code-box that you are creating a new class that implements the PacketHandler interface, and also extends the Player class. Why do you extend the Player class? I mean, as I see it, a Player class defines a model for someone in a game, and a PacketHandler would be something to handle a Packet for that specific Player. But you are recreating a new Player everytime you are creating this new PacketHandler. You should instead create the Player class when someone starts to play, because that is this users Player-model.[/quote]

And expanding on this, openice123, think of an interface as a class which is always abstract, which is true. An interface is always abstract and can only contain abstract methods. Every field inside of an interface is also always a constant. You do not need to even have modifiers such as [tt]public[/tt], [tt]abstract[/tt], [tt]static[/tt], or [tt]final[/tt] when dealing with the methods and fields, because they are always constant and abstract.

Read full topic

item.title: Little question with interfaces
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Script o = (Script) c.newInstance();

OK Pwnd, but you are assuming that every class in the Scripts directory implements/extends Script. This may well be true for you, but if this guy doesn’t have something like that, whatever the reason, then reflection would be useful for determining if the class implements a certain interface.

Read full topic

item.title: Little question with interfaces
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

An interface can be seen as a specification fow a minimum requirement of methods in a certain class. When you implement an interface in a class, that class must contain all the methods that is contained in the implemented interface. You can of course still add new methods to this class aswell, as a normal class, but to add all methods contained in the interface is a minimum requirement.

Using interfaces would be a good idea when you know what methods you will be using in your project/package, but not the exact implementation. This means, people that uses your interface in a class, can implement these methods anyhow they like, but they need to be there.

Another good thing with interfaces is that you can have them as a container for constants, that is “public static final”. So, instead of importing a constant by class or static import, or extending a class that have constants, you now can implement (using “implements”) it instead.

The last but not least thing about interfaces I will mention, is that you can change the implementing classes without compiling the classes that uses these interface. That is, you only have to compile the implementing classes, unless you change more.

openice123: I noticed in your second code-box that you are creating a new class that implements the PacketHandler interface, and also extends the Player class. Why do you extend the Player class? I mean, as I see it, a Player class defines a model for someone in a game, and a PacketHandler would be something to handle a Packet for that specific Player. But you are recreating a new Player everytime you are creating this new PacketHandler. You should instead create the Player class when someone starts to play, because that is this users Player-model.

item.title: Little question with interfaces
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:2, topic:235197”]Reflection.[/quote]No need, really.

Here’s some really old code from an IRC bot I was working on.
I used an abstract class rather than an interface, however, they’re similar.

package info.pwnds.irc.util.script;

import info.pwnds.irc.Main;

/**
 * Date: May 21, 2007
 *
 * @author Robert Saunders (Pwnd)
 * @todo this
 */
public abstract class Script {

    public Script() {
    }

    public abstract String getName();

    public abstract String getCommand();

    public abstract String getHelp();

    public abstract boolean run(String[] args);

    protected void logToChat(Object o) {
        Main.getStreams().sendText(Main.getChannel(), o.toString());
    }
}

[code]package info.pwnds.irc.util.script;

import info.pwnds.irc.Main;

import java.io.File;
import java.net.URL;
import java.net.URLClassLoader;
import java.util.ArrayList;

/**

  • Date: May 21, 2007

  • @author Robert Saunders (Pwnd)

  • @todo this
    */
    public class ScriptHandler extends ClassLoader {
    private ArrayList scripts = new ArrayList();
    private ArrayList running = new ArrayList();

    public ScriptHandler() {
    }

    public void loadScripts() {
    Main.log(“Loading scripts!”);
    if (!scripts.isEmpty()) {
    scripts = null;
    scripts = new ArrayList();
    }
    try {
    File dir = new File("./Scripts/");
    URLClassLoader ucl = new URLClassLoader(new URL[]{dir.toURL()});
    for (File f : dir.listFiles()) {
    if (f.getName().endsWith(".class")) {
    Class c = ucl.loadClass(f.getName().replace(".class", “”));
    Script o = (Script) c.newInstance();
    scripts.add(o);
    Main.log("\tLoaded Script Class - " + o.getName() + “[” + o.getCommand() + “]”);
    }
    }
    } catch (Exception e) {
    e.printStackTrace();
    }
    }

    public ArrayList getScripts() {
    return scripts;
    }

    public Script getScript(String cmd) {
    for (Script s : scripts)
    if (s.getCommand().equals(cmd))
    return s;
    return null;
    }

    public Script getScriptByName(String name) {
    for (Script s : scripts)
    if (s.getName().equals(name))
    return s;
    return null;
    }

    public boolean isRunning(Script s) {
    for (Script run : running) {
    if (run.equals(s))
    return true;
    }
    return false;
    }

    public void runScript(String cmd) {
    if (cmd.equals(“reload”)) {
    loadScripts();
    return;
    }
    String[] parts = null;
    if (cmd.contains(" “))
    parts = cmd.split(” “);
    else parts = new String[] { cmd };
    try {
    Script s = getScript(parts[0]);
    if (s != null) {
    if (!isRunning(s)) {
    running.add(s);
    if (!s.run(parts))
    Main.log(”[ERROR] Script " + s.getName() + " failed!");
    running.remove(s);
    } else
    Main.log(“Script " + s.getName() + " is already running.”);
    } else
    Main.log(cmd + " is not a command.");
    } catch (Exception e) {
    e.printStackTrace();
    }
    }
    }
    [/code]

Wow, more than a year old.

Read full topic

item.title: Little question with interfaces
item.dc:creator: @openice123 openice123
item.description:
@openice123 wrote:

I have just begun to figure out how to semi use interfaces. I still don’t quite get them.
Anyways, I was wondering how would I be able to get a main class to load all the other classes that have the interface implement/loading the interface.

Sorry if I worded it wrong, but I just started using them about 2 hours ago.

edit:
im really dont care about my grammer and puncuation

Im using this for my private server, and all the other sites are to dull to even know what a parameter is, so ill post here.

This is my interface that i am using for handling packets

[code]package FA.Constructors.Packets;

public interface PacketHandler {

public void packet(int packetId, int packetSize);

}[/code]

heres a class implementing the interface

[code]package FA.Constructors.Packets.CurrentPackets;

import FA.Constructors.Packets.PacketHandler;
import FA.Players.Player;

public class Packet121 extends Player implements PacketHandler {

public void packet(int packet, int packetSize) {
	if(packet == 121) {
		frames.sendMessage("hi");
	}
}

}[/code]

now i want a class named Packets to what you guys call “reflect it” or for me load all the classes that are using the interface

this is where im stuck at…

[code]package FA.Constructors.Packets;

import java.util.ArrayList;

import FA.Constructors.Packets.CurrentPackets.Packet121;

public class Packets {

	private ArrayList<PacketHandler> packets = new ArrayList<PacketHandler>();

public Packets() {
	packets.add(new Packet121());
}

}[/code]
